comments.text:
By the way, many games from UE5 run with deferred rendering. For something like Valorant which I believe is forward, yes Framegen WOULD add latency like any other setting. However for games that utilize UE5 features like DLSS, Luman, and Frame Gen are already running in deferred rendering mode such that any of these options are already PAID FOR in terms of end to end latency. In Marvel Rivals, even if I turn off DLSS and Frame Gen, the latency doesn't improve because the game is already designed to be deferred. 

I prefer forward as I like crunching my latency as low as possible, even avoiding filtering and msaa because I am super sensitive to latency and I can feel it over the smallest changes. However, NVIDIA Framegen already forces you to use Reflex. That combined with the fact that Rivals runs deferred, your not increasing your latency, just getting the same amount as your base framerate.

The same cannot be said for mixing technologies. On my 4079, FRS and AMD Framegen add significant latency, it's practically unplayable.

So tl;dr, the latency isn't really bad depending on your framerate as it's already being paid for. There is a better argument to say f*ck TAAU, DLSS, LUMEN, or any other post processing that utilizes deferred rendering. I'm legit like very new to game development and this is the first thing I learned when optimizing UE5. Chat were cooked.

comments.text:
So, let me see if I understand Nvidia's math here.... Jensen says "let's give them a 5080 that is the same price and performance as the outgoing 4080 super to ensure we don't accidently give users more frames per dollar if they buy last generation, but let's also extend that scaling all the way back to RTX 3080 / 3080 Ti and ensure that we're still forcing our customers to shell out roughly the same dollars per frame of performance while we push more game devs to incorporate more RTX 5000 exclusive features like DLSS 4 and MFG while making Ray tracing 100% mandatory... At this rate, we'll never have to make faster hardware again, we can just pour everything into AI for even more upscaling, we can generate six MFG frames with RTX 6000, and by RTX 7000 and DLSS 7, instead of 15 out of 16 pixels being generated by AI, we'll just upscale from 480p all the way to 8K and Multi Frame 16x can generate 15 8K AI frames for every 1 real 480p rendered frame, over 7million pixels generated by AI for every real pixel rendered, allowing us to cut the hardware on our flagship to a 10th of an RTX 5080 and drop back down to 8GB of VRAM, we'll call it the RTX 7080 and MSRP will be $1500 netting us a solid $1300 in gross profit per unit, almost as much margin as we've been making on our datacenter products!" The more you buy, the more you save!

"And just wait for our next killer feature, no native rendering whatsoever! The GPU will generate 99.99% of all pixels via AI inference, the game engine will toss our AI a few hints about what it might want to show on screen in just a 12x12 pixel grid and DLSS 10 will go to work upscaling it to 8K while giving you 5000 AI generated 8K frames per second".

comments.text: It’s entirely possible that big game developers and GPU manufacturers like NVIDIA work in cahoots to keep the upgrade cycle going. Many games push "next-gen" graphics with features like ray tracing, often poorly optimized or barely improving gameplay—while new GPUs conveniently launch to "support" them. Some games even have inflated system requirements that don’t match their actual visuals, making older hardware seem obsolete faster. NVIDIA also locks software features behind newer cards, even when older ones could likely handle them. If progress was the real goal, we’d see better optimization and efficiency, but instead, it feels like controlled obsolescence. Coincidence? Maybe. 😏

For frame gen for most for action games the lag time after 60 game engine made frames is not able to be felt while in scenery games it is more like 30 game engine made frames as nothing is moving that fast and the reason for frame gen is to make it a consistent frame rate instead of bouncing all over the place. Why the scenery games are able to get away with 1/2 the frame rate base? Nothing really is moving while action games almost everything is always moving. So frame gen in a scenery game is only needed if you need V-sync or G-sync to not have tearing due to the heavy load on your GPU.

comments.text: It's interesting that when AMD releases CPU's that are more efficient, everyone goes nuts gushing over it. Nvidia releases new GPU that is more efficient, it gets shit on. The brand-cult thing in the PC gaming world is so weird. Also the sense of entitlement and outrage is telling. There are so many many people that waste away their lives playing video games instead of acquiring skills in the real world and contributing to society in any meaningful way. Then they cry about not being able to afford the very latest technology to play their video games while crying about capitalism and price hikes on Reddit. The level of ignorance is crazy too. Like, seriously, crying about prices and raging over some socialist propaganda that posted a profit chart or price chart is so cringe. There is this thing called inflation, and it has impacted everything. The profit numbers and the price numbers are not comparable to the numbers from before the locked-in 25-50% inflation. comments.text:
Get used to it.  GPU manufacturers are pretty much out of options at this point.  The frame generation is really good.  It's only going to get better - - - and it seems silly to complain about it.  At least if you actually understand that we are AT THE LIMITS of hardware right now.  The ONLY improvement is going to come on the software side.  At the time of writing this comment, NVidia is the #3 most valuable company in the world behind Apple and Microsoft.  It ain't because of their GPUs.  I'm not saying they're bad - - but the REASON NVIDIA is literally on top of the entire world (top 3) is because of their position in the world on artificial intelligence.

I can PROMISE you that A.I. is going to be the future of graphic processing.  The hardware has hit its limits - and this is the main reason the jump from the last generation is not as large as many were hoping.  It's because the HARDWARE isn't improving at the same pace.  It is very possible that NVidia are about to run away in the GPU space due to their VERY LARGE prominence in the A.I. field - which is VERY LIKELY the direction most other manufacturers are going to be going (because they are going to have the exact same hardware limitations that NVidia has.  Except - - none of those other companies are anywhere near as heavily involved in the A.I. game as NVidia.  

All this to say that frame generation benefits everyone.  It has to - - because there is literally NO OTHER OPTION.  You CANNOT DO IT with HARDWARE ALONE anymore.  People need to start accepting that.  A.I. and frame gen are here to stay; it's not just NVidia that will be doing it.  EVERYONE will be - - - and right now, NVidia is the king of the world in that space - - - BY FAR - - and it had NOTHING to do with GPUs until now.

I'm sure you will agree that NVidia has been a monster player in the GPU space for a very long time.  GPUs are basically at a point where they are going to be VERY LARGELY based on software and less and less on hardware.  You have a company that is one of the leaders in the GPU space - - - - that is literally #1 in the A.I. space - - - - 

I just find it a little humorous that people are GRIPING about all the A.I. and frame generation stuff.  The GPUs are about to be so mind-blowingly good in 10 years that you people are going to look back and roll your eyes at the fact that you were griping about frame gen.

comments.text: It's sad that fiduciary responsibility to investors forces Nvidia to release products like this. Everyone in the world knows that regardless of price, stock will sell out immediately, and so they're obligated to keep raising prices to the point where price/performance barely moves across generations. The only solution is to invest in being able to ship out more cards, but that eats into net profits, which is difficult to justify to a volatile market that hates risk. So we're stuck in an endless loop of Nvidia coming out with stuff that is genuinely impressive but inflated to the point where they stop being enticing.

comments.text:
TL;DR don't buy Nvidia unless they have a feature you literally can't live without. In the case of most PC and/or PCVR gamers, AMD is an excellent alternative.

In March 2024 my wife's old GTX 1050 Ti died. I scraped together what money I could for an unexpected GPU purchase at the time. I managed to grab an RTX 4060 Ti. I kept it, and gave her my RTX 3060. About two weeks later, I took my 3060 back and gave her the 4060 Ti (remember, she came from a dying 1050 Ti, she did not care about the 3060/4060 swaps). The 4060 Ti was worse.

In November '24 I gave the 4060 Ti to her brother for free, gave my wife my 3060, and bought myself an AMD RX 7800XT. Screw Nvidia and their nonsense. I only wanted to play games in 1080p ultrawide (2560 x 1080) at 75 fps, but the 4060 Ti just didn't have enough power or VRAM at only 8GB. Which is really ridiculous, since the 3060 (NOT THE TI VERSION) has 12GB VRAM and generally performed better for me. It's also kinda silly that the 4060 and 4060 Ti have the same amount of VRAM. I actually tested both of those cards (4060/4060Ti) in my system, and they performed almost identically for me; VRAM maxed out, framerates dropping.

For reference, all 3 cards referenced above were tested with these specs:
AMD Ryzen 5 7600X
ASRock B650M PG Riptide WiFi
Teamgroup DDR5 (5200 MHz) RAM.
WD Black SN770 Gen 4 m.2 SSD

The only reason to buy Nvidia at this point is if they have a feature that you absolutely require. Otherwise, making the switch to AMD was much easier than I expected. I decided to do a fresh install of Windows for the new card. It's working flawlessly in all my games, and it's a beast. Stays super cool, too. Don't think I've seen the core temp go above 60c. It's a little power hungry; I've seen the total draw reach 250w+ after some slight tweaking of clock speeds and core voltage. However, my old EVGA 850W PSU from like 2019 seems to handle everything great.

comments.author: @6ghastlyghoul9

comments.text:
@6ghastlyghoul9  You mean you can't get 120 fps at 4K max settings with Ray Tracing on and DLSS and Frame Gen off. With that I agree, demanding modern titles in the last 5 years will not typically get above 100 fps average with that configuration. But if you turn either ray tracing off, or DLSS ON (or both) then you will be definitely getting 120 fps average if not far more. Point being, 4K maxed out gaming is not viable with ray tracing still unless you are OK with using DLSS. If you don't like DLSS then you must turn ray tracing off or be happy with 70 fps average.

However, I have no issue with DLSS and personally I don't care that much about ray tracing. DLSS actually does not cause input latency, it is Frame Gen which causes that. And DLSS new version has basically no discernable visual difference from native res. 

So I partially agree with you, but all you have to do is flip 1 or 2 switches and you can easily get 120 fps avg in 4k. 

For me I think 4k is unnecessary, I'll stick with 1080p and 1440p for a long time to come. 4k is not worth the investment you have to make in GPU and computer for lackluster performance. I'd rather just play in 1440p and get super high frames and have the option to turn on or off any settings I want without having to worry about frame rate.

comments.text:
Lets cross our fingers and hope Intel might start creating some competition for both AMD and Nvidia. We need a GPU company to start focusing on hardware, not AI bogus software. 
AI is hype and works well for stocks, but it's not going to sell massive amounts of GPUs. How many people will actually use DLSS 4 seeing as it have so many noticable issues? 
Even if i was a unaware user I'd turn on DLSS and probably swap back to nothing simply because it "feels sluggish" and "something looks strange in the game".
Oh and give it a few years and these cards AI tech will be so outdated it will be pretty much a detriment to use in games, especially seeing as RAM is a major issue already. 
Combine that with an outrageous price for performance and the possibility that Nvidia might start demanding a premium fee for "DLSS SUPER", which seems more and more likely since their app release and considering they are a publicly traded company, and I'm absolutely looking for something from a competitor. They have soo much to lose that I wouldn't be surprised if they start making panic moves like that and took a note out of Microsofts playbook.
If there was a hardware, non-public GPU company on the market now they would sell crazy amounts of graphic cards.

The reasons for its "inconsistencies" with different creator's results is that the Steam version of Black Ops 6 massively underperforms compared to the same game on the Battle net launcher for some reason. Not sure about the Gamepass version, but the Steam version is the really borked, screwed up one. So for those that want high, consistent framerates (& when I say this, it's really noticeable), the Battle net version is superior. Kind of a dumb thing if you ask me & unsure if it's a mistake (tho it has been this way since launch), if it's actually something that the game & Steam are conflicting with each other or whatever, but that's the state of the game. I still use the Steam version because I don't want to buy the game twice & I don't have a problem with my GPUs reaching my FPS cap, but I can see this being an easy mistake for people trying to test performance.

comments.text:
I have a different experience with AI gen frames in BO6. 

Ive got a 4070ti Super and 7800x3d and I’m pretty picky with maximizing gaming performance I can get with that game because of the twitch aim needed—I even have an 240hz OLED monitor because I’m pretty sensitive to input lag (I play on controller.)

 But even so, I play tested with AI Frame Gen on vs off, and I didn’t actually feel any difference in my movements and aiming with it on. I don’t feel any input lag at all, but I do get more frames, all 240 of them all the time. 

Frame Gen is even better with the new graphics cards for input lag, so I can definitely see Frame Gen being the new “true frames” once it gets indistinguishable from raw performance. 

I mean, who wouldn’t want a huge boost to their fps while also having a smaller graphics card that draws less power if the frame gen is good enough

comments.text:
So just a quick tip to any would be buyers: The 50 series cards are not targeted at 40 series owners, they are targeted at the masses (roughly 70% of the market - probably closer to 80-85% if we're being honest) that are still using a 30 series or older. Reviewers tend to forget that the majority of gamers aren't using 40 series cards, they're using old ones and only focus on comparisons to 40 series, well because it's much easier to go negative and it's also kind of Youtube's thing. Death to Nvidia! :P Are these great cards? For a 40 series owner? Nope, for a 30 series owner? They're actually pretty good.

For those 40 series owners. If you're looking for 30 to 40 series level growth, stop buying video cards now. It's not going to happen in one generation ever again. That was 8nm to 4nm, that's a pretty massive density change, that will never be repeated because there just isn't that much density left to be had. 4nm to 3nm won't be that big of a change. Barring architecture innovation? Generational growth has already peaked.

You're best bet if you require that kind of uplift? Wait a few generations, let the improvements accumulate.

comments.text:
NVidia is trying to shove more AI processing onto a raster card so they can sell it to gamers AND AI model-ers. The problem is that gamers hate fake frames and upscaling. Turning them on still looks like a ghosty vaseline smear. I'm not paying $1000 to play a game that looks like it's being streamed via video online with artifacting, smearing, etc.

They should have put LESS AI cores onto it and more CUDA or pure raster die space. They could have killed it. But they tilted for the smeary frame windmill and are going to not sell well to gamers and lose market share to Intel this generation.

This reminds me a lot of Intel's 14nm road block. NVidia hasn't had much architectural raster improvement in 10 years per-core, they just ride on process nodes shrinking and then market their AI smearing.

This is the moment when Intel and AMD can catch up and capture a slug of the market in this generation's 2 years of life.

I understand that AI and framegen will be the new focus, and nvidia will likely continue to improve this technology over providing substantial raw performance gains. It's disappointing, but it is what it is. What I'm more excited for is these handhelds and mini pc's getting such insane performance lately with AMD's apu's. comments.text: My bet is that 4090s and 4080 Supers won't drop in prices, because people won't want to upgrade away from the 40 series, and there won't be a sufficient supply-demand gap. Regarding the gen-on-gen performance is easy to explain if you understand the underlying engineering challenges, the performance is bottlenecked, by silicon and interconnect. Architecture can help, but not enough. Which is why the emphasis on software tricks rather than pure compute power growth. Engineering at the top end is now hurting profit margins, which is why AMD don't want to challenge in the premium range. For Nvidia, the problem won't be resolved until the Rubin refresh.

comments.text: I think one thing a lot of creators are forgetting is that the whole "Generational Leap"....for a long time it was only 10-15% boosts each release. Starting with the 3000 series we saw a pretty big leap for the first time in a long time. Even when you look at the 1080 vs 2080, it was only a 10-20% difference in most games, and in some games even less. That was the norm for a long time. Then we got the 3000 series, and we saw a big leap. Part of it was because of the DLSS changes and RTX getting a big buff, but natively they were still a bigger boost than what we were used to. Then we got the same situation again with the 4000 series. 2 generations in a row just blowing the previous one out of the water. Now we're at the 5000 series and we're back to small gaps in performance and calling it a joke? This is how things were for decades before. I'm not trying to defend Nvidia here, but the same goes for AMD. It looks like the new AMD GPU's will be only a small bump in performance but are we going to call it a joke? Lets have a conversation about the real joke....The pricing, availability, and the people who are going to buy these up anyway.

comments.text:
Smoothing out gameplay in my mind is not a bad thing but I think that depends heavily on as you said the starting framerate.  If you're trying to do frame gen on a game running at 20 fps the visual difference between each frame at 20 FPS is going to be FAR greater than a game running at 60+ FPS.  I think being able to make things that are running at 60 to a buttery smooth 180 FPS without having a big hit visually or only having artifacting that you will only notice if you're looking really hard for it is a good thing for gamers.  That being said, I think that this tech isn't a good excuse for NVidia releasing new cards that barely bump performance at such a high cost. 

More than anything we need way more competition in the GPU Space.  Just having AMD and NVidia isn't healthy.  Intel is there too now but they aren't really competing.

comments.text:
Looking at it realistically, and not with my feelings, I would buy a 5080 if I was in the market for a new GPU. That's with some big assumptions. That I can get it at MSRP or below ($999). That 4090s aren't available for $800 or less. Right now, a 4090 is $2500. A 5080 can deliver virtual 4090 performance in CP2077, according to what I've seen so far from more qualified reviewers (60+ fps @ 4K is why I would buy a 5080). It would be a bargain at 1000 bucks compared to what's available today. Unfortunately, I highly doubt they will be easily available at MSRP. Which means they will be in demand, despite what those with pre-Covid/pre-Inflation/AMD competitive believe.
All that said, the biggest problem with the 5080 for me is the 16GB RAM. The same amount as my 4070ti Super. So I'll be waiting for the 5080ti with more RAM, or more likely, the 60 series. I have 2 gaming PCs and leapfrog the GPUs.

comments.text:
0:32 

Thanks for the great content but i have to correct you here but also not.
Let me explain:
As an electronics engineer, microprocessor nodes are my field of study.
Nvidia used the 4N (a renamed 5N) TSMC process node (5 nanometers) in the 40 series gpus
And used the 4NP TSMC process node (also 5 nanometers "enhanced" , but only 7% denser) in the 50 series gpus.
So i am not surprised that the efficiency gains are very close or equal to 0.

Why didn’t they use 3 nanometers or 4 nanometers you might ask?
- Because they saved all of those for Rubin and the gb10 superchip for? yes, you guessed it right (Ai only tasks)
And we consumers get the (6 years old)! Technology in our 2000$ 5090 !!!
Don’t believe me?
Google it
When did TSMC introduce the 5 nanometer process node?
It was 2019 btw.

Thats the reason why the rtx 50 series sucks
The reason is: Ai.

If you have any questions, i am happy to help.

comments.text:
@victoryensured7137  
"I have a summarization at the end if you don't have time".

     The 2080 super is built on the 12nm tsmc process node.
The 5080 is on the 5nm process.  It will always depend on your cpu and ram, But assuming that you use a ryzen 7 5700x with ddr4 3600.
I would personally say that the 5080 is a nice big jump for you.  At least 2.4x better than the 2080 super in rastraization.
So if you play cyberpunk at high settings at 4k 30 fps  now, The 5080 will give you around 70-80 fps potentially bottlenecking your cpu if you enable dlss performance.

     Speaking of Dlss and mfg they could make the 5080 more appealing to you but i am just comparing raster now.

     In my opinion, if you can, hold on for the super refreshes, maybe the prices of these 5nm gpu's will come down.

     But if you are REALLY patient, wait for the 60 series, Nvidia cant keep just increasing the size of the 5nm die forever.  The will be forced to use 4nm ,3nm or hopefully 2nm.

"This section is just me imagining a good life".

     Dude If we imagine that the 6080 uses the 2nm process node, it would be 2.5x faster while using less power and producing less heat than the 5080 also 6 times faster than the 2080 super
So instead of 4k 30
You will play at 4k 180fps natively!.  Simply put, Instead of fake generated 240 fps with dlss, this card will do those 240 fps natively without any dlss or mfg, and then dlss and mfg could support it.  Anyways that will happen in 2027 if and only if Nvidia decided to give us good cards which is unlikely.

     Also amd will release a 9070 xt for around 500-600$ (hopefully) in march, which will match the 4070 ti super in path tracing and the 4080 in rastraization, but unfortunately they are not available in all countries at stock price or at all sometimes.
Imaginary section ended.

That's my opinion.

To summarize:
1- 2080 super to 5080 is a 240% jump in rastraization.
2- i suggest waiting for the super refreshes next year for more price to performance.
3- an "imaginary" 6080 on a 2nm process node in 2027, will be 250% faster than current 5080 and 600% faster than a 2080 super in pure rastraization performance, while using less power and producing less heat than the current 5080.
4- wait for what amd (if they  are available in Poland) has to offer, maybe they will go hard on the price to performance game, and maybe you will like their cards.

comments.text:
​ @ChaxO7  Firstly i always have time for sound advice from a knowledgeable person, secondly i always read the post in it's entirety if I started the exchange especially when I ask a question, It's just basic human respect towards a speaker (or writer in this case). Thirdly thank you VERY much for a really in depth comment and advice.

Jumping straight to the point my specs not including my trusty old RTX 2080 Super (Zotac) are as follows: 

Mainboard: Asus Prime Z690P D4
CPU: Intel i7 12700k 
RAM: Kingston Fury 2x16GB DDR4 3600MT/s
Be Quiet 750W Platinum

So about the waiting game, I am a patient person, i never rush into a buy although I am not a godlike expert on all cases regarding computer components and newer technology (I am a little behind, life gets to you and time waits for no one, also i got kinda bored with gaming and hobby programing, spent too much time on it in the past and my gods it's getting complicated with all the AI) 

Getting back to the subject when 30x series was released a year after I bought my Super it flyed by me so fast and i was disappointed (wtf?! i just bought the 20x series and it's not top anymore? My pride took a hit) but thought ok, no big deal, there is always bigger fish in the pond. Then the 40x came and the prices where insane (also Covid hit and increased the demand while supply chain distruption was an issue, ramping the prices, not to mention the everlasting scalping disease), but ok thought its a rough time for all, we must endure and wait, they will decrease in price. 

They never did. To this day. The same case was with the 30x series. Ok they are a bit cheaper and avalible but still, not close to a margin that i would pay for a 30x series. 

Same with 40x series, they are almost non existent on our market anymore (some scalper prices like 4k can be found on local sites but cmon, we need to weed them out, burn the heretic, for the emperor..) and even in stores the prices are 3k and eternally nor avalible. 

You know what advice I am always given when I'm hunting for a GPU? Wait. Always. Wait. Just wait. A little. It will be better. It NEVER does. Neither the price, nor the performance (it's always less than thought performacne wise and more $ wise. Always.)  Sometimes you just need to make a jump. And I'm always happy with my buys. Always. 

This ,,discrepancy" in this reality is kicking me hard. I can wait. I know I do. But also playing on lower settings that I was used to due to the fact that the games today need more work on them and the developing process is lets just say... not functioning properly (thats an understatement am I right?) is getting really uncomfortable. 


And not all of it is Nvidia's fault (looking at you devs. Are you winning yet son? Well.. are you?) 

I really enjoyed your "This section is just me imagining a good life" paragraph. It's a thing that i hope will change as per your description and I like to think in an optimist frame of mind often, but usually reality is more rapidly molding me into a pessimist in this regard. 

But really to sum it all up I think your right,I should wait, I'm at my limit though, still have some bigger finacial commitments than can supersede this whole ,,upgrade me pls" PC master race (don't get me wrong I still love it, I really do, i love the thirll of getting new components, the "slickness" of the build<no RGB for me, black matte look pls> , the thirll of the upgrade.. but I'm tired man.. It goes to fast the technology. I think I"m old? Also the lack of avalabilty REALLY kills me and my drive for this) but I will WAIT again for the supers and the Ti-s. 

Also If I don't make it (patience wise)till next year I'm going for the heavenly touch. I'm going all out. 5090. If they finally make them ffs. Oh and AMD sucks donkey balls xDXDXDXD sry guys. I'm not a fanboy. Oh god I'm not, but had once AMD, never NEVER again. 

Sory for the long post. 

Cheers!

comments.text:
I'm ashamed it took me this long to find this channel but it's now one of my current favorites. I appreciate this take and I echo many of the sentiments. I'm not a Luddite who angrily opposes AI, but I also hate how quickly it seems to be taking over all conversations around technology these days--as a sort of band-aid to hardware limitations. 

That said, AI-driven frame generation and lower power consumption seem to be the way things are headed. It definitely adds value, but it'll take time before people fully accept it as a real replacement for the raw benchmarks of native resolution and power-hungry performance testing we're used to.

comments.text:
Everyone thinks about generational upgrades.  What about folks entering the market?  I was told that the 11900k was trash coming from a Ghost Canyon i9.  The 11900k was great in comparison.  I know, SFF; however, I gained all types of I/O options above the last generation in addition to AVX-512 to be used in MatLab.  It wasn't a waste of sand.  Gamers expect everything for nothing.
Please think of those new to the game or gaming as I was.  I was only trying to get a new PC for school and research.  That 11900k is still running strong alongside a 12600K, 13850HX -ES, and a 13900K.  I am finding it so hard to part ways with it. Now that 13900k and it's tuning issues, I get.

As far as GPU's, don't buy them and stop complaining.  Gamers are the most bandwagon group there is, cry babies.  I look forward to the 5090 if they are available in sufficient numbers without scalping.  I have two 3090 XC3 Ultras NVLinked for acceleration and AI research, two 3080 XC3 Ultras for the boys, and a 3060ti XC Ultra from the Ghost Canyon sale, a 3060 or 3080 Tuf 10GB in Thunderbolt enclosure (Mantiz Saturn II or another smaller one I can't recall it's name) for use with personal and school/business laptops when traveling to professional developments and trainings.

Remember, this is entertainment.  These folks have e motivations beyond simply reviewing.  Take it with a grain of salt.

comments.text:
Just something I've actually noticed that may need to be corrected. 

From what I have read from sources online, the Nvidia RTX 40 series and RTX 50 series GPUs are both manufactured on the same TSMC 4N (5nm) node, which means that there isn't really any real gains for efficiency and transistor density.

I think this explains why we're seeing similar levels of scaling between the increases in core count, performance and power draw across the board, as the only realistic way to get more raw performance when using the same manufacturing node would be to brute force more cores, power and clock speeds where possible. That also explains why the RTX 5090 has the crazy 575W TDP rating.

comments.text: 4:39 some review (possible LTT) said that framegen makes the most sense when you need it the least - I think this confirms your findings well. It really only works well when the starting point isn’t too bad, and that isn’t really when you’d really want it.
comments.author: @rasmusvedel

comments.text: That shouldn't come as a surprise at all. The statement of "when you need it the least" is misleading, or the target audience is wildly misinformed. You'd want interpolation for motion clarity, and it mostly does deliver on that. The main usecase, in my opinion, is going from very high refresh rates (min 80fps, better >200fps) to refresh rates higher than you can perceive. If you need better latency, interpolation just is the wrong tech alltogether. One promising option is frame reprojection, and in the VR space a lightweight version of that has been in use for over a decade. NVidias Reflex 2 is a step in that direction, but there's a lot of room for improvement.
comments.author: @davidruppelt

comments.text:
Hot take: Don't understand me wrong, I would love to have massive performance increases, the 5000 series is rather dissapointing for now. But I actually think for gaming, not having a meaningful performance increase for one or two generations is great. It forces software to become more efficient and is a heavy driver for innovation, not just in games. 
The current trend of just consuming more power to increase overall performance for hardware is the wrong way, that is obvious to everyone. it is by far the easiest way, but a sustainable and good way is never easy.  It may be boring and dissapointing, but in the long run, such scenarios are often more exciting with greater benefits than just getting more raw power.
Any chance you could start including 1440p testing in your benchmarks?

@notacat  Cool- THANKS! I guess, everything will be going the way of NPU's in the future. Many jobs will be lost.

A Neural Processing Unit (NPU) is specifically designed to accelerate AI and machine learning tasks, while a Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) is primarily focused on graphics rendering, meaning an NPU is better suited for AI-related operations compared to a GPU, even though GPUs can also handle some AI tasks; essentially, an NPU is more optimized for artificial intelligence processing than a GPU is.

comments.text:
It's probably inevitable that teams that struggle to hit fps will look at MFG to rescue them last minute; but I think it's unlikely a game would aim at low fps from the get-go, unless there's a massive jump in reliability or maybe the specific game works really well with MFG (like mostly static/slow scenes in an RPG or something).
In my experience Art directors and rendering engineers still look at AI with a bit of distrust, because they simply don't know what final image quality will be like, and what to do about it if it looks wonky. So it's a "if the player wants to mush the quality for frames, they can, but our game still needs to look great out of the box" mindset. Which is nothing new, you could already go into the settings panel and force disable texture filtering and what not.

comments.text:
"I have no idea how Nvidia thought this was ok"

I'll tell it why they thought it's ok......it's because there's no other option. Process node improvements are hitting the diminishing return point because of the limits of physics that are out of their control. Nvidia are actually geniuses because they saw the writing on the wall early on and invested and bet on AI which is the only solution to this problem that will only get even worse with time. The future of further improvements to graphics and graphical performance requires a new paradigm that allows for a new Moore's law curve in effect. That new paradigm is AI. The implementations of the AI that we have now are extremely primitive though but it's early days. Instead of using AI to upscale pixels and generation fake frames, in the future, there will be no need for these implimentations of AI as AI will take over the "real frame" rendering entirely. This will happen slowly over time, graphically piece by piece, parts of the brute force method of rasterisation and ray tracing will be swapped with AI methods that are exponentially more efficient at achieving the same if not better result. Eventually then, there will come a point where the "real frame" is entirely AI generated (meaning technically 100% "frame gen" at that point? lol). Long story short, Nvidia are actually the Hero's here. Yes it sucks the effectively non existent performance gains from the 50 series (outside of MFG) but that's not Nvidia's fault. If anyone was to blame, it's TSMC for not innovating fast enough lol but even that is not true as they're working as hard as they can but they're hitting the wall on the laws of physics for improvement rate to process nodes (ergo, Nvidia CEO saying "Moore's law is dead" is correct). The good thing is, AI allows for a new paradigm in process node technology to be eventually found (if it can) as AI allows for the same process node to see exponential rates of improvement in the field of AI without improvements to process nodes. Can you even imagine what happens when whilst we're still in the exponential phase of the AI Moore's law curve and process node innovation finds a way to restart the Moore's law curve on that? Moore's law^2

Moores law actually points against what you're saying. The problem is that Moores law is no longer true, and that there is a logarithmic disparity between processor transistor speed and memory speed.

The reality is though that even with Moores law no longer being as applicable as it was this uplift is bad. If Moores law was changed by a factor of 4 (doubling of transistors every 8 years),  then even still this was a bad release

We can optimize architecture, but that wont net huge gains. Next thing to do is build bigger stuff, which will come with diminishing returns. So all things considered, while there will be improvements for decades to come, the entire concept of computing is reaching some kind of limits right now. However, there is still completely untapped technology, like visual computing, or, for AI, analog computing. So those ideas will probably be explored more and more the less and less incentive there is to invest into the current approaches. But to reiterate.. we are not there yet.

comments.text:
​ @agree69  Depends on what your focus is. Overall this is a difficult and kind of missleading statement. Let me explain. 
Nowdays you have multiple orders of magnitude more amazing games to play that 15 years ago. Per day, dozens of games get released, a few of them could be considered masterpieces. There are new exciting games every day that do something groundbreaking or are better than what came before.  The thing is, if you only look at AAA games from a few large publishers, then it seems like a terrible time, that is true. If you take a look at the big picture, gaming has never been more amazing. 
Never have there been more games released, never have there been more people that make games with passion, never has the shift in hardware and software features to make games been greater,  never have games been cheaper (for now at least, if Rockstar will not succeed with their 100USD GTA6), never have games been more accessible, never has diverse hardware been more capable to run all kinds of games and never have games been more diverse.

​ @AWSimDrifter  The problem withg smartphone cameras is not that there is no innovation and possibilities to make better camera hardware, it is that the size constraints of phones are extremely limiting. 
There is a lot of new tech for phones, massively bigger sensors, liquid lenses for wider focus range etc. The problem is that it is not viable to dedicate 200USD or 300USD of manufacturing cost towards the camera. For now, really innovating at that point for phone cameras is not impossible, but really hard and expensive. There would be many vays to innovate and many technologies that already exist but have not been used in phones. The other problem is that a new feature has be liked by the masses and cannot just appeal to a niche. Well... not in todays economy and mindset.
@samueladitya1729  Basically dead since 2022 at this point.

@alexis1156  The 5090 undervolts and overclocks like a champ.  You can run it at 400W with an overclock and no performance loss.  For my purposes, running local LLMs (and gaming), the 512-bit 32GB high bandwidth VRAM is going to be awesome, and I'll be able to run and fine tune smaller models much faster than my MacBook Pro.  DLSS is a nice perk too for certain games.  I wish it was 48GB though.

Also, the video encoders that support 4:2:2 and AV1 encoding are a nice benefit.  If you don't want to run LLMs with it, or do productive work, and are just interested in gaming, I can understand your perspective.  I think the VRAM should have been increased on all cards though in the 50 series.

comments.text:
Lots of AMD hating here although we already see that Nvidia dropped from the Highend too. Yes 5090 is an upgrade, but you won't be getting one, since the availability is so low. So if you get 5070 TI or 5080, you basically get the same midrange performance that 4080 already offers, so 9070 XT might actually be somewhat competitive.

So who did win in this generation? Probably not any of us unless AMD really presses on the price wars, which we know they love to miss the opportunity.

Some even say that AMD can't do DLSS or FrameGen, but the way I look it now is that AMD now has catched up on NVidia with those techs, so Nvidia was forced to something else again (AI rendering stuff that isn't in games, at least yet). 

So looking it that way FSR4 will be as good as DLSS for most people and FrameGen is already supported in every single game outside of even official support, by using Fuild Motion Frames 2 from the control panel. They were probably betting on those techs to compete until well, Nvidia had a perfect Apple like marketing with AI in CES, so they backpedaled.

comments.text:
You Nvidia haters are something else. The end result is all that matters, not how you get there. Upscaling and frame generation is industry standard now, has been for a long time, even before DLSS it was on consoles. In 99% of cases it looks identical, and feels just as responsive, especially with reflex. DLSS has been out for 4+ years now, its in most games that launch by default, its a natural Anti Aliasing solution, and quality mode is just as good as native, if not better in some edge removal cases. Like objectively, Darktide and BlackOps 6 framegen/reflex play and feel amazing. They are direct examples of proving how good this tech is. 

Why do you even need more OLD rasterization horsepower? What modern game is launching now without DLSS or FSR? Ok older games need it? What older game struggles to run on modern GPUs of today? 

I've been gaming since the Crysis 1 days, we would've killed for DLSS / Frame gen to get the best visuals AND performance. Its literally magic and little snarky loosers like you turn your nose up to it so ignorantly. Your loss duummy!

@ okay on second thought, maybe you weren’t being sarcastic and trying to be helpful. This is yet another case of someone complains about something and the rest follow the herd and now we actually have people saying some video game frames being generated are fake 😂 
Its all a fake video game being rendered as well as our really fancy calculators can - FG just analyzes what you are doing and inserts a frame in between to make your game feel smoother, it’s all happening in 1/60th of a second or faster.

comments.text:
I actually got into an argument with a friend a few weeks ago because a mutual (3rd) friend had just ordered a 40 series card for his new build.  My friend's exact words were "That is stupid with the 50 series about to come out."  Referencing the 2080ti I bought in 2020 and could have sold 12 months later used for 50% more than I paid for it new, my argument was basically "Between supply issues, scalpers, Nvidia being Nvidia, and the unknown, if there's a card that you're happy with now you should absolutely pull the trigger on it.  It's also not like you can't upgrade down the road."  

I wouldn't say I "called it", but I definitely feel like I've been proven right and the new cards aren't even out yet.

comments.text:
Then don't buy it. 

I don't get what all this complaining is about. Moore's law is dead, and you cannot expect steady improvements in raster performance every year. I'd be happy to be proven wrong by AMD or intel, but I've been waiting for a few years now. So If nvidia is able to generate additional performance using DLSS, I don't see what's wrong with it? If you don't like DLSS, don't use it lol. DLSS hasn't ruined the industry, lazy game devs have. We would have been in the same situation even if we got all this performance gain from rasterization instead of DLSS. Games will always keep up with any generational performance gains we see with new hardware, be it through rasterization or AI. Even if tomorrow AMD somehow comes up with a revolutionary new architecture that delivers 10x the performance for the same power draw, the gaming industry will eventually develop games that will make it seem underpowered.

comments.text:
@MV-ri7zu be less disengenuous. It just hurts the case you're trying to make. According to Steam's hardware survey, only 5% of gamers are using 4k, & that's the only resolution where you can get away without AA. The other 25% at 1440 & 50% at 1080 (yes, those don't add up to 100% because there are in fact other resolutions) cannot get away with what you're describing as "the best" because it'll fill their screen with shimmering artifacts, which are MUCH worse & more distracting than what DLAA provides. I was calling out how horrible previous iterations of DLSS were too. Horrible ghosting & artifacts galore. Over time though, DLSS has gotten much better & the new model is genuinely impressive. It makes DLAA the best AA on the market, even better than MSAA.

I'm very tired of the two extremes who either worship DLSS and FrameGen vs those who hate on them mindlessly. As is usual, the truth lies somewhere in the middle. FrameGen is still a fundamentally flawed tech as it's less useful in cases where you really need extra frames and less necessary in cases where you already have said frames. Modern DLSS, however, has come a hell of a long way and is finally in a great place. Does it still have flaws & artifacts? Absolutely. Is it in a place where those things have been largely addressed? Also absolutely.
